metadata.unitName: TEST orange Forces Shape Earth's Surface

questions.question: Which sequence lists Earth’s layers from the outermost to the innermost?

answers.content: Crust, mantle, outer core, inner core
answers.explanation: This is the correct order described in the lesson notes and model.

answers.content: Mantle, crust, inner core, outer core
Crust, outer core, mantle, inner core
Mantle, outer core, crust, inner core

questions.question: Which layer of Earth is mostly liquid iron and nickel?

answers.explanation: The outer core is a hot, liquid layer composed mainly of molten iron and nickel.

questions.question: Why does Earth’s inner core remain solid even though it is as hot as the surface of the Sun?

answers.content: The immense pressure at Earth’s centre keeps the inner core solid.
answers.explanation: High pressure prevents the iron–nickel alloy from melting at that temperature.

answers.content: It is made entirely of rock, which cannot melt.
The inner core is cooled by the mantle.
It contains large amounts of water, which keeps it solid.

questions.question: Name the layer of Earth that is made of semi-solid rock and moves very slowly, driving surface changes such as volcanic eruptions.
Draw a cross-section of Earth showing all four main layers. Label each layer and use a different colour for each one.

answers.content: Drawing includes crust, mantle, outer core, inner core all correctly positioned and labelled.
answers.explanation: Full mark awarded when all layers are present, correctly ordered and labelled.

questions.question: After falling through the crust in the cartoon, which layer would Scrat reach next?

answers.explanation: The mantle lies directly beneath the crust.

questions.question: Describe how temperature generally changes as you move from Earth’s crust toward the inner core.

answers.content: It increases / gets hotter the deeper you go.

questions.question: The crust is thicker beneath ________ than beneath ________.

answers.explanation: Continental crust is thicker than oceanic crust.

questions.question: What is the immediate cause of an earthquake?

answers.content: The sudden release of built-up stress along a fault between tectonic plates
answers.explanation: Stress builds where plates grind or stick; when it is suddenly released the ground shakes.

questions.question: What name is given to the large, slowly moving pieces of Earth’s crust that interact to produce earthquakes?

answers.explanation: Earth’s lithosphere is broken into tectonic plates whose movements cause most earthquakes.

questions.question: In the Mars-bar model used in class, which component represents Earth’s crust?

answers.content: The solid chocolate coating on the outside
answers.explanation: The hard outer layer mimics the brittle crust that fractures during plate movement.

questions.question:
Complete the sentence using the causal connective ‘so’ to show cause and effect:
“The earthquake struck the Noto Peninsula, _____ the coastline was permanently lifted.”

answers.explanation: ‘So’ links the cause (earthquake) and the effect (coastline lifted). Any grammatically correct completion using ‘so’ earns full marks.

questions.question: If the epicentre of an earthquake is under the ocean, what additional natural hazard is most likely to form?

answers.explanation: Seafloor movement displaces water and can generate tsunami waves.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple diagram that shows two tectonic plates locked at a fault and the arrows indicating the direction they move when an earthquake occurs.

answers.content:
Model answer rubric: 
• Two separate blocks labelled ‘Plate A’ and ‘Plate B’ (0.5 mark)
• A jagged line between blocks labelled ‘Fault’ or ‘Plate boundary’ (0.5 mark)
• Arrows showing opposite or converging movement of plates (0.5 mark)
• Caption or note indicating ‘Stress builds → sudden slip = earthquake’ (0.5 mark)
answers.explanation: Award partial marks according to rubric; full 2 marks for all four features.

questions.question: What is the molten rock called before it reaches Earth’s surface?

answers.explanation: Molten rock inside Earth is called magma; once it erupts it is called lava.

questions.question: Which immediate change to the landscape can result from a volcanic eruption?

answers.explanation: Cooling lava can solidify and build new landforms such as islands or mountains.

questions.question: Which pair correctly matches a volcanic term with its definition?

answers.content: Lava – molten rock that flows out of a volcano
answers.explanation: Lava is magma that has reached the surface and is flowing outside the volcano.

answers.content: Magma chamber – cloud of gas above a volcano
Eruption – underground pool of liquid rock
Vent – layer of fertile soil made by ash

questions.question: The eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD helped archaeologists learn about Roman life because

answers.content: Ash buried the city, preserving buildings and artefacts for centuries
answers.explanation: The rapid burial protected everyday objects, providing a ‘time capsule’ of ancient Rome.

answers.content: Lava created gold statues of Roman citizens
The eruption was filmed by scientists
Romans wrote books during the eruption

questions.question: Explain one positive and one negative knock-on effect of volcanic eruptions on the environment. Use causal connectives such as “because”, “therefore” or “as a result”.

answers.content:
Positive: Volcanic ash breaks down into mineral-rich soil. Therefore, plants grow more vigorously and farming can thrive.
Negative: Ash clouds block sunlight and contaminate air and water. As a result, people and animals may experience breathing difficulties and crops can fail.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple diagram of a volcano showing the magma chamber, main vent and lava flow. Use arrows to indicate the path magma takes during an eruption.
What is the name of the process that breaks down rocks into smaller pieces on Earth’s surface?

answers.explanation: Weathering is the term for the physical or chemical breakdown of rocks.
Erosion moves already-broken pieces away but does not break them down.
Deposition is the laying down of eroded material.
Fossilisation is the preservation of once-living things in rock.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an agent of weathering discussed in this lesson?

answers.explanation: Electricity was not mentioned as an agent of weathering in the lesson.

questions.question: In the classroom investigation, what action was used to simulate the weathering of rocks?

answers.content: Shaking sugar cubes or soft rocks in a closed container
answers.explanation: The shaking caused the cubes/rocks to knock together, mimicking natural abrasion.

answers.content: Heating the rocks with a lamp

questions.question: Describe the difference between weathering and erosion.

answers.content: Weathering is the breaking down of rocks in place; erosion is the movement of the broken material away by wind, water, ice or gravity.

questions.question: Give two ways that moving water can weather rocks.

answers.content: Flowing rivers carry sand and small particles that scrape rock surfaces; ocean waves repeatedly crash against rocks causing them to chip and smooth.

questions.question: Which causal connective in the model paragraph was highlighted as new to students?

answers.explanation: "Due to" was the new causal connective pointed out in the lesson.

questions.question: What coloured paper was placed under the rocks to help observe tiny weathered particles after shaking?

answers.explanation: Black paper was chosen so light-coloured rock dust would be easy to see.

questions.question: List the three main agents of weathering that the interactive focused on.
Draw and label a simple diagram showing how plant roots can weather a rock.

answers.content: Student’s drawing should show a rock with a growing root entering/expanding cracks and pushing the rock apart, labelled ‘root’, ‘crack widens’, and ‘broken rock pieces’.

questions.question: Why does weathering usually take a very long time in nature compared with the classroom investigation?

answers.content: In nature the forces (water flow, wind, root growth) are weaker and act slowly, so many years of repeated action are needed to break rocks apart, whereas shaking in class applied strong, constant force in a short time.

questions.question: What is meant by the term erosion?

answers.content: The breaking of rocks into smaller pieces on Earth’s surface
answers.explanation: This describes weathering, not erosion.

answers.content: The movement of rocks, soil and sand from one place to another
answers.explanation: Erosion is the transport of weathered material.

answers.content: The dropping of sediment in a new location
answers.explanation: This is deposition.

answers.content: Molten rock erupting from a volcano
answers.explanation: This is volcanic activity, unrelated to erosion.

questions.question: In the tray investigation, which variable was CHANGED to test its effect on water-caused erosion?

answers.explanation: The same amount of water was poured into each tray.
Each tray used the same damp sand.
Only the slope was altered by adding books under the tray.
Students drew the same river length in each tray.

questions.question: Which tray is expected to show the MOST erosion?

answers.explanation: Water moves slowest on a flat tray, so it carries away least sand.
Some erosion occurs, but not the most.
The steep slope makes water flow fastest, increasing its force and ability to erode.

questions.question: Explain WHY water flowing down a steeper slope causes more erosion than water flowing on a gentle slope or flat surface.

answers.content: A steeper slope makes water move faster. Faster-moving water has more kinetic energy/force, so it can pick up and carry more sand, soil and small rocks away, producing greater erosion.

questions.question: Identify TWO things that had to stay the SAME in the tray investigation to keep it a fair test.

answers.content: Sample answers: the amount of water poured each time; the type and amount of sand; the length/shape of the river channel; size of tray.

questions.question: Which sequence correctly orders the three related processes discussed in this lesson?

answers.explanation: Incorrect order.
Rocks are first broken down (weathering), then transported (erosion), then dropped (deposition).
Incorrect order.
Incorrect order.

questions.question:
Draw and label the river channel in Tray 3 (steep slope) AFTER the water was poured. Your diagram should: 
• show the path of the water, 
• indicate where most sand accumulated, and 
• include arrows or labels that explain the direction of water flow and areas of greatest erosion.

answers.content: Teacher-scored: Look for accurate depiction of steeper slope, widened/deeper channel, sand collected at bottom, arrows showing fast flow.

questions.question: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples explain the creation of landforms through Dreaming stories such as ‘Super Snake’. How does this cultural explanation DIFFER from the scientific explanation introduced in the lesson?

answers.content: Dreaming stories describe landforms as being created by ancestral beings, whereas science explains them through natural forces like wind and water.
answers.explanation: This highlights differing world views—spiritual vs. physical processes.

answers.content: Dreaming stories focus only on wind erosion, while science focuses only on water erosion.
answers.explanation: This is not an accurate comparison.

answers.content: Dreaming stories do not mention landforms at all.
answers.explanation: They do mention them.

answers.content: There is no difference; both explanations are identical.
answers.explanation: They differ in perspective and mechanism.
